natural problem: Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square?
natural solution: Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.

We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.

Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}

1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem max_slips_no_square
fixes draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<longrightarrow> draw n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<longrightarrow> draw i * draw j \<noteq> (isqrt (draw i * draw j))\<^sup>2"
shows  "card {i. \<exists>j. j \<in> {1..16} \<and> draw i = j} \<le> 11"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem max_slips_no_square
fixes draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<longrightarrow> draw n = n"
and h1 : "\<forall>i j. i < j \<longrightarrow> draw i * draw j \<noteq> (isqrt (draw i * draw j))\<^sup>2"
shows  "card {i. \<exists>j. j \<in> {1..16} \<and> draw i = j} \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: For a draw function where the output is equal to the input for numbers between 1 and 16, and where the product of any two different outputs is never a perfect square, what is the maximum number of distinct outputs the function can have? The final answer is 11.

a_1.formal problem:
This problem involves a complex process of random drawing and checking for perfect squares, which is beyond the scope of Isabelle's current theorem-proving capabilities. However, the problem can be rephrased in a simpler way that can be expressed in Isabelle:

Natural language version: "Given a set of integers from $1$ to $16$, find the maximum size of a subset such that no two numbers in the subset have a product that is a perfect square. The final answer is $11$."

This can be translated to Isabelle as:

theorem
fixes S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S ⊆ {1..16}"
and h1 : "∀ a b ∈ S. a ≠ b ⟶ ¬ is_square (a*b)"
shows  "card S ≤ 11"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$

 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

This problem involves a complex process of random drawing and checking for perfect squares, which is beyond the scope of Isabelle's current theorem-proving capabilities. However, the problem can be rephrased in a simpler way that can be expressed in Isabelle:

Natural language version: "Given a set of integers from $1$ to $16$, find the maximum size of a subset such that no two numbers in the subset have a product that is a perfect square. The final answer is $11$."

This can be translated to Isabelle as:

theorem
fixes S :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "S ⊆ {1..16}"
and h1 : "∀ a b ∈ S. a ≠ b ⟶ ¬ is_square (a*b)"
shows  "card S ≤ 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given a set of integers from 1 to 16, find the maximum number of elements that can be selected such that the product of any two distinct elements selected is not a perfect square. The final answer is 11.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes draw :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "set draw \<subseteq> {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> set draw \<and> y \<in> set draw \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> \<not> perfect_square (x * y)"
shows  "length draw \<le> 11"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem
fixes draw :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "set draw \<subseteq> {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> set draw \<and> y \<in> set draw \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> \<not> perfect_square (x * y)"
shows  "length draw \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: You have a set of distinct natural numbers from 1 to 16. How many numbers can you draw from this set such that the product of any two different numbers drawn is not a perfect square? The maximum number of numbers you can draw is 11.

a_3.formal problem:
The given problem is a combinatorial problem with no direct mathematical equation or formula, and cannot be directly translated into an Isabelle language version as it is more suitable for a programming language or algorithmic approach. 

However, a possible way to represent the problem in Isabelle would be:

consts 
  slips :: "nat set"
  draw :: "nat set => nat"
  product :: "nat * nat => nat"
  perfect_square :: "nat => bool"

axiomatization
where
  slips_def: "slips = {1..16}" and
  draw_def: "∀x. draw x ∈ slips" and
  product_def: "∀x y. product (x, y) = x * y" and
  perfect_square_def: "∀x. perfect_square x ⟷ (∃y. y * y = x)"

theorem max_draws:
  "∃n. n = 11 ∧ (∀m. m ≤ n ⟶ (∀x y. x ∈ draw m ∧ y ∈ draw m ∧ x ≠ y ⟶ ¬ perfect_square (product (x, y))))"
  
Note: The above Isabelle representation is a theoretical and simplified representation. It does not consider the randomness and 'without replacement' condition of the drawing process.
a_3.formal solution:

 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.

The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.

The given problem is a combinatorial problem with no direct mathematical equation or formula, and cannot be directly translated into an Isabelle language version as it is more suitable for a programming language or algorithmic approach. 

However, a possible way to represent the problem in Isabelle would be:

consts 
  slips :: "nat set"
  draw :: "nat set => nat"
  product :: "nat * nat => nat"
  perfect_square :: "nat => bool"

axiomatization
where
  slips_def: "slips = {1..16}" and
  draw_def: "∀x. draw x ∈ slips" and
  product_def: "∀x y. product (x, y) = x * y" and
  perfect_square_def: "∀x. perfect_square x ⟷ (∃y. y * y = x)"

theorem max_draws:
  "∃n. n = 11 ∧ (∀m. m ≤ n ⟶ (∀x y. x ∈ draw m ∧ y ∈ draw m ∧ x ≠ y ⟶ ¬ perfect_square (product (x, y))))"
  
Note: The above Isabelle representation is a theoretical and simplified representation. It does not consider the randomness and 'without replacement' condition of the drawing process.
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: The problem is about a set of slips numbered from 1 to 16. Two slips are drawn without replacement from this set. We are looking for the maximum number of times we can draw two slips such that the product of the numbers on the two slips drawn is not a perfect square. The answer is 11 times.

a_4.formal problem:
theorem max_slips
fixes slips :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "slips = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> slips \<and> y \<in> slips \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> \<not> is_perfect_square (x * y)"
shows  "card slips \<le> 11"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem max_slips
fixes slips :: "int set"
assumes h0 : "slips = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> x y. x \<in> slips \<and> y \<in> slips \<and> x \<noteq> y \<longrightarrow> \<not> is_perfect_square (x * y)"
shows  "card slips \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: Consider a set of slips of paper, each with an integer from 1 to 16 written on it. If no pair of distinct slips can be chosen such that the product of their numbers is a perfect square, what is the maximum number of slips that can be in the set? The final answer is 11.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes jillian_draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "jillian_draw 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> n > 0 \<longrightarrow> jillian_draw n = jillian_draw (n-1) + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> n > 0 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>m. m > 0 \<and> m < n \<and> is_square (jillian_draw m * jillian_draw n)) = False"
shows  "Max {n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> jillian_draw n = n} = 11"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem
fixes jillian_draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "jillian_draw 0 = 1"
and h1 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> n > 0 \<longrightarrow> jillian_draw n = jillian_draw (n-1) + 1"
and h2 : "\<forall>n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> n > 0 \<longrightarrow> (\<exists>m. m > 0 \<and> m < n \<and> is_square (jillian_draw m * jillian_draw n)) = False"
shows  "Max {n. n \<in> {1..16} \<and> jillian_draw n = n} = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Jillian has a unique way of drawing. On her first day, she drew 1 item. For each of the following 16 days, she drew one more item than she did on the previous day. However, she never drew in such a way that the product of the numbers of items she drew on any two different days was a perfect square. What is the maximum number of items she drew on any given day during these 16 days? The final answer is 11.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem maximum_slips:
fixes maxSlips :: nat
assumes h0 : "maxSlips = 11"
and h1 : "\<forall>setPile. setPile \<subseteq> {1..16} \<and> size setPile = maxSlips \<longrightarrow> 
            (\<nexists>x y. x \<in> setPile \<and> y \<in> setPile \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> perfect_square (x*y))"
shows  "maxSlips = 11"
where "perfect_square n = (\<exists>k. k*k = n)"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem maximum_slips:
fixes maxSlips :: nat
assumes h0 : "maxSlips = 11"
and h1 : "\<forall>setPile. setPile \<subseteq> {1..16} \<and> size setPile = maxSlips \<longrightarrow> 
            (\<nexists>x y. x \<in> setPile \<and> y \<in> setPile \<and> x \<noteq> y \<and> perfect_square (x*y))"
shows  "maxSlips = 11"
where "perfect_square n = (\<exists>k. k*k = n)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: "Suppose we have a pile that consists of a subset of numbers from 1 to 16, and the size of this pile is 11 (let's call this maximum number of slips). The pile is arranged in such a way that there are no two different numbers in the pile whose product is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips? The final answer is 11."

a_7.formal problem:
theorem max_slips
fixes draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i<16. draw i \<in> {1..16} - {draw j |j. j < i}"
and h1 : "\<forall>i<j. j<11 \<longrightarrow> \<not> perfect_square (draw i * draw j)"
shows  "draw 11 \<in> {1..16} - {draw j |j. j < 11}"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem max_slips
fixes draw :: "nat \<Rightarrow> nat"
assumes h0 : "\<forall>i<16. draw i \<in> {1..16} - {draw j |j. j < i}"
and h1 : "\<forall>i<j. j<11 \<longrightarrow> \<not> perfect_square (draw i * draw j)"
shows  "draw 11 \<in> {1..16} - {draw j |j. j < 11}"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: In a contest, slips numbered from 1 to 16 are drawn. For any draw $i < 16$, the number on the slip is distinct from any previous draws. If the product of any two numbers drawn in the first 10 draws is not a perfect square, find the possible numbers that could be on the 12th draw. The final answer is any number from 1 to 16 that has not been drawn in the first 11 draws.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem max_slips_without_perfect_square_product:
fixes slips :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "set slips = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n1 n2. n1 \<in> set slips \<and> n2 \<in> set slips \<and> n1 \<noteq> n2 \<longrightarrow> \<not> is_perfect_square (n1 * n2)"
shows  "length slips \<le> 11"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

theorem max_slips_without_perfect_square_product:
fixes slips :: "nat list"
assumes h0 : "set slips = {1..16}"
and h1 : "\<forall> n1 n2. n1 \<in> set slips \<and> n2 \<in> set slips \<and> n1 \<noteq> n2 \<longrightarrow> \<not> is_perfect_square (n1 * n2)"
shows  "length slips \<le> 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: You have 16 slips of paper, each labeled with a distinct number from 1 to 16. If you choose two distinct slips, the product of the two numbers is never a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips you can have? The final answer is 11.

a_9.formal problem:
The problem involves a lot of concepts from probability, combinatorics and number theory, which are quite challenging to formalize in Isabelle. However, a rough attempt to formalize this problem could look like this:

datatype slip = Slip int

definition slips :: "slip set" where
"slips = {Slip n |n. 1 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 16}"

definition draw :: "slip set ⇒ slip set" where
"draw S = S - {s. ∃x y. x ∈ S ∧ y ∈ S ∧ x ≠ y ∧ perfect_square (product x y)}"

definition perfect_square :: "int ⇒ bool" where
"perfect_square n = (∃m. m * m = n)"

definition product :: "slip ⇒ slip ⇒ int" where
"product (Slip n) (Slip m) = n * m"

definition max_draws :: "int" where
"max_draws = Max {n. ∃S. finite S ∧ S ⊆ slips ∧ card S = n ∧ draw S = S}"

theorem "max_draws = 11"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Each of the integers $1,$ $2,$ $3,$ $\dots,$ $16$ is written on a separate slip of paper and these slips are placed in a pile. Jillian will randomly draw slips from the pile without replacement and will continue drawing until two of the numbers she has drawn from the pile have a product that is a perfect square. What is the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw without obtaining a product that is a perfect square? The final Answer is 11
 ### Proof
 Recall that an integer is called square-free if the only exponent which appears in the prime factorization of the integer is $1.$ For example, $2\cdot3\cdot11$ is square-free, but $7^3\cdot13$ and $2^2\cdot3$ are not.
 We define the "square-free part" of a positive integer which is not a perfect square to be largest square-free factor of the integer. For example, the square-free part of $18$ is $6,$ and the square-free part of $54$ is $6.$ Perfect squares have a square-free part of $1.$
 Notice that two positive integers multiply to give a perfect square if and only if either their square free parts are equal or the integers are both perfect squares.
 Therefore, if we look at the square free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16,$ the maximum number of slips that Jillian can draw is the number of distinct square free parts that appear. The table below (broken into two lines) shows the square-free parts of the integers between $1$ and $16.$ \begin{tabular}{cccccccc}
 1 & 2 & 3 & 4 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 8 \\ \hline 1 & 2 & 3 & 1 & 5 & 6 & 7 & 2 \end{tabular} \begin{tabular}{cccccccc} 9 & 10 & 11 & 12 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 16 \\ \hline 1 & 10 & 11 & 3 & 13 & 14 & 15 & 1 \end{tabular} Jillian may draw the slips marked $5,$ $6,$ $7,$ $10,$ $11,$ $13,$ $14,$ and $15,$ as well as one from each of the sets $\{1,4,9,16\},$ $\{2,8\},$ and $\{3,12\}$ for a total of $\boxed{11}$ slips.
 *)

The problem involves a lot of concepts from probability, combinatorics and number theory, which are quite challenging to formalize in Isabelle. However, a rough attempt to formalize this problem could look like this:

datatype slip = Slip int

definition slips :: "slip set" where
"slips = {Slip n |n. 1 ≤ n ∧ n ≤ 16}"

definition draw :: "slip set ⇒ slip set" where
"draw S = S - {s. ∃x y. x ∈ S ∧ y ∈ S ∧ x ≠ y ∧ perfect_square (product x y)}"

definition perfect_square :: "int ⇒ bool" where
"perfect_square n = (∃m. m * m = n)"

definition product :: "slip ⇒ slip ⇒ int" where
"product (Slip n) (Slip m) = n * m"

definition max_draws :: "int" where
"max_draws = Max {n. ∃S. finite S ∧ S ⊆ slips ∧ card S = n ∧ draw S = S}"

theorem "max_draws = 11"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: In a bag, there are 16 slips of paper, each labeled with a distinct integer from 1 to 16. Two slips are drawn at a time from the bag, and if the product of the numbers on the two slips is a perfect square, then both slips are discarded; otherwise, both slips are returned to the bag. What is the greatest number of slips that could be left in the bag after this process cannot be continued? The final answer is 11.
